conclusion: To calculate the distance traveled by the car within 60 seconds, analyze the acceleration-time graph and use kinematic equations.
From t = 0 to t = 10 seconds, the car accelerates at 2 m/s².
From t = 10 to t = 30 seconds, the car moves at a constant velocity (acceleration is 0).
From t = 30 to t = 60 seconds, the car decelerates at -1 m/s².
Calculate velocity from t = 0 to t = 10 seconds using v = u + at: v = 20 m/s.
Velocity remains constant at 20 m/s from t = 10 to t = 30 seconds.
Calculate velocity from t = 30 to t = 60 seconds using v = u + at: v = -10 m/s.
Calculate distance from t = 0 to t = 10 seconds using s = ut + 1/2at²: s1 = 100 m.
Calculate distance from t = 10 to t = 30 seconds using s = vt: s2 = 400 m.
Calculate distance from t = 30 to t = 60 seconds using s = ut + 1/2at²: s3 = 150 m.
Sum the distances from each interval: s_total = 650 m.
The distance traveled by the car within 60 seconds is 650 meters.
